content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" is cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports by the Congressional Budget Office and Committees, completion of action on budget resolutions and reconciliation legislation, and consideration of appropriation bills in the House. The congressional budget process includes deadlines for budget submission, completion of action on reconciliation legislation, and consideration of appropriation bills. Key dates include June 15 for reconciliation legislation, June 30 and August 1 for biennial appropriation bills, and October 1 for the start of the fiscal year. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, with a new President, specific dates will override the usual deadlines. The budget submission and approval process has specific deadlines to be followed by the President and Congress, starting from the first Monday in April to August 1st. If it's the first session of Congress after a leap year with a new President, different dates will apply. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills, defense appropriation bill, and reconciliation legislation. On October 1, the fiscal year begins. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture and Commerce, Justice, Science. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define a biennium as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations are adjusted to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define a biennium as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations are adjusted to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. Additionally, amendments are made to subsections (b) and (f)(2)(A) to specify budget allocations for defense and all fiscal years covered by the resolution. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve changing references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for various sections related to balance statements, functions and activities, allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, and tax expenditures. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve changing references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for various sections related to balance statements, functions and activities, allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, and tax expenditures. This includes adjustments for future years, prior year outlays, and tax expenditures. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve changing references from "the prior fiscal year" to "each of the 2 most recently completed fiscal years" for various sections. This includes adjustments for prior year receipts, estimated expenditures of legislative and judicial branches, and recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies. Additionally, Section 1105(b) is amended to specify that estimates are made each even-numbered year. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve changing references for estimated expenditures of legislative and judicial branches. Section 1105(b) is amended to specify estimates are made each even-numbered year. SEC. 5. TWO-YEAR APPROPRIATIONS; TITLE AND STYLE OF APPROPRIATIONS ACTS. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will follow a specific format for each fiscal year in a biennium, while defense Acts will have a different format. All Acts making regular appropriations must detail the amounts provided for each fiscal year. The text chunk specifies definitions for terms used in appropriations Acts and makes a technical amendment to the table of sections in title 1 of the United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless the program will require no further appropriations. Exceptions include defense, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless the program will require no further appropriations. Exceptions include defense, privileged measures, matters in Executive Session, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. Additionally, the table of contents in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section after section 315. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT requires joint oversight hearings by relevant committees on agency activities not funded under certain conditions. The hearings review agency mission, impact of biennial budgeting, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD is also addressed. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will assess the impact of transitioning to a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting in fiscal year 2017.
